questions.text: You are suspecting a case of delayed puberty in a 15-year-old boy. To assess puberty in this patient, what is the first sign you would look for?
questions.solution:
The first sign of puberty in males is the increase in testicular volume.

In males at 11 to 12 years, the growth of the testis (>4 mL in volume) and thinning of the scrotum occurs, which are the first signs of puberty. This is followed by the pigmentation of the scrotum, growth of the penis, and pubarche.
Growth of testis > pubarche > adrenarche > growth spurt (TPAG).

In females at 10 to 11 years, the breast bud (thelarche) appears, which is the first sign of puberty followed by the appearance of pubic hair (pubarche), growth spurt, and menarche. 
Thelarche > pubarche > growth spurt > menarche (TPGM).

questions.text: As an intern, you are currently posted in the Paediatric endocrinology OPD where you see multiple cases of girls having precocious puberty. The condition is defined by the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of_________.
questions.solution:
Precocious puberty is defined as the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years in girls and 9 years in boys.

Depending on the primary source of hormonal production, precocious puberty can be classified in the following manner:

Central Precocious Puberty

(Gonadotropin-dependent puberty)

Peripheral Precocious Puberty

(Gonadotropin independent)

Due to the excess secretion of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) from pituitary

Due to excess secretion of testosterone or estrogen from the gonads/adrenals.

Always isosexual (appearance of phenotypically appropriate secondary sexual characteristics before age 8 years in girls and before 9 years in boys).

Can be isosexual or heterosexual (appearance of secondary sex characters of the opposite sex).

Girls 

  • Idiopathic (most common)

Boys

  • CNS pathology (most common)

Girls 

  • Estrogenic ovarian cysts (isosexual)
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) (testosterone increases; heterosexual)

Boys

  • CAH (isosexual; most common)

Note:

Central Precocious Puberty(more common) >> Peripheral Precocious Puberty

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl was brought to the OPD by her mother who is concerned about her significant increase in height compared to her classmates in the last 2 years. On examination, the girl shows breast development corresponding to B2 Tanner stage. What is the most common brain lesion causing this condition?
questions.solution:
Hypothalamic hamartoma, a neuronal migration defect, is the most common cause of organic central precocious puberty. The onset of breast development before the age of 8 years in females and onset of testicular development (>4 mL) before the age of 9 years in males is suggestive of central precocious puberty. 

It is a congenital malformation that consists of ectopically located neural tissue characterised by-

  • Early-onset of puberty
  • Seizures associated with unnatural crying or laughing episodes are known as gelastic seizures.

Tuberculous meningitis, tuberous sclerosis, and astrocytomas can also cause central precocious puberty.

questions.text: A young girl was referred to the paediatrician with stage IV breast development and growth acceleration seen at the age of 5 years. Her estradiol concentrations were elevated. The sagittal MRI of the brain is as shown below. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
A pedunculated mass in the floor of the 3rd ventricle as shown in the MRI, with elevated levels of estrogen is suggestive of a Hypothalamic Hamartoma, which is the most common brain lesion causing central precocious puberty and is treated with GnRH agonists. 

Treatment of Hypothalamic Hamartoma-

  • GnRH agonists (depot-forms or implant) are the treatment of choice of tumour-induced Central precocious puberty                                                                                                  
  • In patients with hypothalamic hamartoma and associated intractable gelastic or psychomotor seizures, stereotactic radiation therapy (Gamma Knife surgery) is more effective and has fewer risks than neurosurgical intervention.


Long-acting formulations of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists are the preparations of choice for the treatment of central precocious puberty as they maintain fairly constant serum concentrations of the drug for weeks or months.

questions.text: A primary school teacher notices bloodstains on the skirt of her second-grade student. She immediately informs her parents and accompanies the child to the doctor on campus. On examination, the 7-year-old girl had blood-stained vaginal discharge, enlarged breasts and areola. Which of the following is not a cause for this condition?
questions.solution:
Vaginal bleeding with well-developed breasts before the age of 8 years is suggestive of precocious puberty. Prader–Willi syndrome is one of the causes of delayed puberty in girls (not precocious puberty), where there is hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

Hypothalamic hamartoma, McCune–Albright syndrome and hypothyroidism are causes of precocious puberty.

Note:

In prolonged hypothyroidism, adolescents typically have delayed puberty. Younger children might present with pseudo-precocious puberty, characterized by breast development and vaginal bleeding in girls and macroorchidism in boys.

Elevated levels of TSH appear to interact with the FSH receptor (specificity spillover), thus inducing FSH-like effects in the absence of LH effects on the gonads. The FSH-like effect suffices to induce estradiol secretion by the ovaries, whereas in males, testicular enlargement occurs without substantial testosterone secretion.

questions.text: An incessantly crying 5-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her father. You observe that she needs support to walk and her trunk is not symmetrically aligned. There is a history of recurrent fractures in her limbs. She also has blood-stained vaginal discharge from a few days. On examination, the girl appears as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Precocious puberty(vaginal discharge), bony lesions (polyostotic fibrous dysplasia), and cafe au lait spots, as shown in the picture, are features of McCune–Albright syndrome. There is pain due to the multiple bony lesions and repeated fractures may result in incessant crying in the children and may require regular visits to the orthopaedics department. 

McCune–Albright syndrome is a classical cause of peripheral precocious puberty caused by a mutation of GNAS1 gene. It affects the bones, skin, and several endocrine tissues.

Fibrous dysplasia of multiple bones (polyostotic) represents a major cause of morbidity in this syndrome. The base of the skull and the proximal femurs are most commonly involved, but any bone can be affected. A CT scan is usually recommended even in absence of deformities. The prognosis is favourable for longevity, but deformities, repeated fractures, pain, and occasional cranial nerve compression may result from the bony lesions.

Cardinal features:

  • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia
  • Cafe au lait macules
  • Endocrine abnormalities: hyperthyroidism, acromegaly, adrenal adenomas, and autonomous ovarian hyperfunction, leading to precocious puberty
  • Predominantly affects girls

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy on examination is found to have genital development corresponding to Tanner stage 1 and his height is below the 3rd Percentile on growth charting. What is the most common cause for this condition?
questions.solution:
Failure of development of pubertal features by the age of 14 years in male is suggestive of Delayed Puberty.

The most common cause of delayed puberty in males and females is a constitutional delay in growth and puberty. Lack of pubertal changes in boys by the age of 14 years is suggestive of delayed puberty. Delayed puberty is more common in boys than in girls.

questions.text: Breast and papillae appear as a small mound on examination of a young girl. If you are suspecting a case of delayed puberty, it is defined as a lack of development of secondary sexual characters beyond the age of __________.
questions.solution: Delayed puberty in girls is defined as lack of secondary sexual characteristics by the age of 13 years or absence of menarche by the age of 16 years or within 3 years of pubertal onset.

questions.text: A child presents with features of delayed puberty. On investigating, he has decreased levels of LH, FSH, and testosterone. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has low levels of luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and testosterone pointing towards hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and Kallman's syndrome is the only condition in the given choices causing hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

Causes of delayed puberty:

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (Secondary/central)

Hypogonadism is due to the impaired secretion of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) by the pituitary gland and the resultant lack of sex steroid production

  • Malnutrition, systemic diseases
  • Kallmann (anosmia), Prader–Willi syndrome (mental retardation, obesity, low intelligence)

Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (Primary gonadal failure)

Hypogonadism is due to an impaired response of the gonads to the gonadotropins (FSH and LH), which in turn leads to a lack of sex steroid production and elevated gonadotropin levels (as an attempt of compensation by the body)

  • Sex chromosome anomalies (Turner's, Klinefelter's syndrome)
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome
  • Ovotesticular dysgenesis

questions.text: All of the following are features of Laurence-Moon-Biedl syndrome except _________.
questions.solution:
Hypertension is seen in Laurence–Moon–Biedl syndrome.

Laurence–Moon–Bardet–Biedl is an autosomal-recessive disorder of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

Characteristic features:

  • Polydactyly
  • Obesity
  • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • Male hypogonadism
  • Hypertension
  • Mental retardation

questions.text: A female child presents with bilateral inguinal masses, which were thought to be hernias but were found to be testes in the inguinal canals. Which karyotype would you expect to find in the child?
questions.solution:
Here, this baby girl with bilateral inguinal masses (testis) probably has androgen-insensitivity syndrome, where karyotype is 46,XY.

Androgen-insensitivity syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the androgen receptor gene that makes XY fetuses insensitive to androgens. The patients phenotypically resemble females because a part of the testosterone is converted to estrogen, which leads to the development of female external genitalia, normal development of breast, and female habitus.

Patients with Klienfelter's syndrome have a karyotype of 47, XXY and can have undescended testis, but they have male external genitalia where the phallus tends to be smaller than average.

Characteristic features:

  • Most common forms of male disorders of sexual differentiation (DSD).
  • 46 XY male child with female phenotype, present with primary amenorrhoea.
  • Normal male gonads, mostly undescended ones, can present as inguinal masses or hernia.
  • Here, as testosterone receptors are defective, they do not act on tissues, leading to the absence of secondary sexual characters (absence of pubic hair and axillary hair).

questions.text: An infant was found to have elevated levels of LH. The baby has a 46, XY chromosome pattern on karyotyping and the vagina is short and ends blindly in a pouch. Which of the following is false in the condition suffered by the infant?
questions.solution:
An infant with a 46, XY chromosome pattern and female external genitalia are suggestive of Androgen-insensitivity syndrome(AIS) where there is absent internal female genitalia.

These patients have absent internal female genitalia with normal female external genitalia with the vagina ending blindly, in a pouch and normal male gonads in the form of undescended testis (mostly) which can present as inguinal masses.

In a male child (46, XY), testicular hormones are resistant to receptors, and a part of the testosterone is converted to estrogen leading to the development of female external genitalia and eventually normal development of breast, and female habitus.

Features of Androgen insensitivity syndrome at different age groups-

  • In infants, elevated LH levels should suggest the diagnosis of AIS
  • Prepubertal females with this disorder are often detected when inguinal masses which prove to be testes
  • In older children and adults, amenorrhea is the usual presenting symptom.

Note:

Reifen-Stein syndrome: Males with various forms of ambiguous genitalia and undervirilization (hypogonadism, severe hypospadias, and gynecomastia). They are phenotypically normal-appearing males with infertility.

questions.text: A 31-year-old female delivers a term baby. On examination, it has a micropenis and unpalpable testis. She gives a history of acne from 16 weeks of gestation which worsened throughout pregnancy and was treated after delivery. The baby was diagnosed to have female pseudohermaphroditism. Which of the following statements are right about the given condition?

choices.text: Female external genitalia and male internal genitalia

questions.solution:
Female pseudohermaphrodites are genectic females (XX genotype) with male external genitalia.

Causes:

  • Enzyme deficiencies: 21 hydroxylase, 11 hydroxylase, and 3-beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase (HSD) deficiencies
  • Maternal androgen excess

Male pseudohermaphrodites are genetic males (XY genotype) with female external genitalia.

Causes:

  • Enzyme deficiencies: 17 hydroxylase and 3-beta HSD deficiencies
  • Defect in androgen action

True hermaphroditism/ovotesticular dysgenesis: An intersex condition in which an individual is born with ovarian and testicular tissue.

questions.text: What is true about ovotesticular disorders of sex development?

choices.text: Ovotestis is seen in the gonadal biopsy
The response of testosterone to hCG is increased.

questions.solution:
Ovotesticular disorder of sex development (DSD) is characterized by the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue in the same individual. An ovotestis is present in approximately 2/3 of affected individuals.

Most affected individuals have a 46, XX chromosomal karyotype, which normally results in female sexual development. In about 10% of patients, testicular tissue in an individual with a 46, XX karyotype is present as a result of a translocation of the SRY gene on the Y chromosome to the X chromosome or another chromosome. There is a defect in R-spondin1 protein encoded by the RSPO1 gene, described in 46, XX ovotesticular DSD. 

An abnormal vagina and an underdeveloped uterus are usually present. The testes are usually undescended, and the penis may present with hypospadias. Upon reaching puberty, breast development, feminization, and menstruation may occur. Most affected individuals are infertile, but ovulation or spermatogenesis is possible. The response of testosterone to hCG is normal or reduced.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl was brought by her mother with complaints of enlarged clitoris. Karyotype revealed 46XX. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a girl (46XX) with an enlarged clitoris is highly suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia/adrenogenital syndrome is a family of autosomal-recessive disorders caused by the deficiency of enzymes involved in the synthesis of steroid hormones in the adrenal cortex. The majority of cases of CAH are caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency. This deficiency leads to a lack of synthesis of cortisol and aldosterone, resulting in the salt-wasting form of the disease, which is the most severe form. 

Severe 21-hydroxylase deficiency presents with symptoms including weight loss, dehydration, weakness, hypotension, and electrolyte imbalances. Accumulated steroid precursors like 17-hydroxyprogesterone, are shunted into the pathway of androgen synthesis leading to elevated levels of androstenedione and testosterone. This can result in abnormal genital development in affected female fetuses during early gestation. 

Females may have masculinized external genitalia. This can include enlargement of the clitoris, partial or complete labial fusion, and a shared opening of the vagina and urethra (urogenital sinus). 

Untreated individuals develop signs of androgen excess after birth.  These signs include accelerated skeletal maturation, premature epiphyseal closure leading to stunted adult stature, excessive muscular development, the appearance of pubic and axillary hair, acne, and deepening of the voice. In males, enlargement of the penis, scrotum, and prostate. In females, the clitoris may become further enlarged. 

Diagnosis of confirmed by elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels. Glucocorticoid replacement with hydrocortisone is done. In a salt-wasting crisis, fludrocortisone supplementation is given. Vaginoplasty and clitoral recession are done for females with ambiguous genitalia. 

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

21-hydroxylase deficiency 17-hydroxylase deficiency 11β-hydroxylase deficiency 3β-HSD deficiency

Deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone

Deficiency of cortisol and sex hormones

Deficiency of cortisol

Deficiency of cortisol, aldosterone, and testosterone

↑ in testosterone

 ↑ in aldosterone ↑ in deoxycorticosterone (mineralocorticoid) and testosterone  ↑ in DHEA
Salt wasting crises Salt retention and  hypertension

Salt retention and  hypertension

 Salt-wasting crises
Virilization of females (ambiguous genitalia 46XX)     Failure of sexual development in females at puberty Virilization of females  (ambiguous genitalia 46XX) Females are mildly
virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)
Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY) Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY)

Note: In 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.
